contentHTML:
HSC BiologyFoundational

The Animal Cell

Explore the structures and functions of animal cells, from the command centre nucleus to the power-producing mitochondria and the protein synthesis pathway through ER and Golgi.

üê≠

üéØ LEARNING INTENTIONS

  • Students can identify and describe the structure of major animal cell organelles
  • Students can explain the function of each organelle in cellular processes
  • Students can trace the pathway of protein synthesis and transport
  • Students can relate organelle structure to its specific function
  • Students can distinguish between animal and plant cell structures

üîó KEY CONNECTIONS

  • Prior: Cell theory, prokaryotic vs eukaryotic cells
  • Next: The Plant Cell (Lesson 4)
  • Future: Cellular respiration, protein synthesis
  • Skills: Diagram labelling, structure-function reasoning

‚úÖ SUCCESS CRITERIA

  • I can label an animal cell diagram with all major organelles
  • I can explain nucleus, mitochondria, ER, and Golgi functions
  • I can describe protein journey from synthesis to export
  • I can explain structure-function relationships
  • I can identify 3+ differences between animal and plant cells
üè¢

Overview: The Animal Cell

Animal cells are eukaryotic cells that make up the tissues and organs of animals. Unlike plant cells, they lack a cell wall and chloroplasts, but they contain a sophisticated array of membrane-bound organelles that work together to maintain life.

üí° Key Concept: Each organelle has a specific structure that enables its function. This structure-function relationship is a fundamental principle in biology. For example, mitochondria have folded inner membranes to maximise surface area for energy production.
OrganellePrimary FunctionKey Structural Feature
NucleusControl centre; stores genetic informationDouble membrane with pores; contains chromatin
MitochondriaEnergy production (ATP) via cellular respirationDouble membrane; folded inner membrane (cristae)
Rough ERProtein synthesis and modificationNetwork of membranes with ribosomes attached
Smooth ERLipid synthesis and detoxificationNetwork of membranes without ribosomes
Golgi ApparatusProtein processing, packaging, and distributionStack of flattened membrane-bound cisternae
LysosomesDigestion and waste removalMembrane-bound vesicles containing enzymes
RibosomesProtein synthesisSmallÈ¢óÁ≤í composed of rRNA and protein
CytoskeletonStructural support and intracellular transportNetwork of microfilaments and microtubules
Cell MembraneRegulates entry and exit of substancesPhospholipid bilayer with embedded proteins
üß¨

The Nucleus: Command Centre

The nucleus is the largest and most prominent organelle in animal cells. It houses the cell's genetic material (DNA) and controls cellular activities by regulating gene expression.

Structure of the Nucleus

ComponentStructureFunction
Nuclear EnvelopeDouble membrane with nuclear poresSeparates nucleus from cytoplasm; controls transport via pores
ChromatinDNA wound around histone proteinsStores genetic information; condenses into chromosomes during division
NucleolusDense region inside nucleusProduces ribosomal RNA (rRNA) and assembles ribosomes
Nuclear PoresProtein complexes in envelopeRegulate passage of molecules between nucleus and cytoplasm
‚ö†Ô∏è Common Mistake: Students often confuse the nucleolus with the entire nucleus. The nucleolus is a structure inside the nucleus responsible for making ribosomes, while the nucleus is the entire organelle containing chromatin.

üìù Worked Example: Nucleus Function

Question: Explain why the nucleus is called the 'control centre' of the cell and how its structure supports this function.

Answer: The nucleus is the control centre because it contains the cell's DNA, which carries instructions for all cellular activities. The nuclear envelope with its pores allows selective transport‚ÄîmRNA can exit to be translated into proteins, while transcription factors can enter to regulate gene expression. This structural arrangement ensures that genetic information is protected yet accessible when needed.

‚ö°

Mitochondria: Powerhouses

Mitochondria are often called the 'powerhouses' of the cell because they generate ATP (adenosine triphosphate), the cell's energy currency, through cellular respiration. Remarkably, mitochondria contain their own DNA and likely evolved from ancient bacteria.

Structure and Function

FeatureStructureFunctional Significance
Outer MembraneSmooth, permeable boundarySeparates mitochondrion from cytoplasm
Inner MembraneHighly folded into cristaeIncreases surface area for ATP synthesis
MatrixFluid-filled interior spaceContains enzymes for Krebs cycle; mitochondrial DNA
CristaeFolds of inner membraneContain electron transport chain proteins for ATP production
üí° Endosymbiotic Theory: Mitochondria have their own DNA, ribosomes (70S like bacteria), and reproduce by binary fission. This evidence supports the theory that they evolved from ancient prokaryotes that formed symbiotic relationships with early eukaryotic cells.

üìù Worked Example: Mitochondrial Structure-Function

Question: Explain how the structure of the inner mitochondrial membrane is adapted for its function.

Answer: The inner mitochondrial membrane is extensively folded into cristae, dramatically increasing surface area. This structural adaptation accommodates more electron transport chain proteins and ATP synthase enzymes. Greater surface area means more sites for ATP production, enabling the mitochondrion to meet high energy demands. This is why muscle cells, which need abundant energy, contain mitochondria with especially dense cristae.

üè≠

The Endomembrane System: Protein Factory

The endomembrane system is a network of membranes that work together to synthesise, modify, package, and transport proteins and lipids. It includes the endoplasmic reticulum (ER), Golgi apparatus, and transport vesicles.

Endoplasmic Reticulum (ER)

The ER is a network of membranous tubules and sacs continuous with the nuclear envelope. It exists in two forms:

FeatureRough ERSmooth ER
AppearanceStudded with ribosomes (looks 'rough')Lacks ribosomes (looks 'smooth')
FunctionProtein synthesis and modificationLipid synthesis and detoxification
LocationAbundant in cells secreting proteins (pancreas, plasma cells)Abundant in liver cells (detoxification) and hormone-producing cells
ProductsMembrane proteins, secretory proteins, lysosomal enzymesSteroid hormones, phospholipids, detoxified compounds

Golgi Apparatus

The Golgi apparatus acts as the cell's 'post office'‚Äîit receives proteins from the ER, modifies them, packages them into vesicles, and ships them to their final destinations.

üß¨

1. CIS FACE (Receiving)

Transport vesicles from ER fuse with cis face and release proteins into Golgi.

‚Üì
‚öôÔ∏è

2. PROCESSING

Proteins are modified‚Äîcarbohydrate groups added (glycosylation), phosphate groups attached, or proteins folded correctly.

‚Üì
üì¶

3. TRANS FACE (Shipping)

Modified proteins are sorted and packaged into vesicles for transport to final destinations.

‚Üì
üöö

4. DESTINATION

Vesicles transport proteins to: cell membrane (for secretion), lysosomes, or other organelles.

üîÑ

Protein Synthesis and Transport Pathway

Understanding how proteins travel from synthesis to their final destination illustrates how organelles work together as an integrated system.

üß¨

STEP 1: NUCLEUS

Gene transcription: DNA ‚Üí mRNA. mRNA exits through nuclear pores.

‚Üì
üè≠

STEP 2: RIBOSOME

Translation: mRNA ‚Üí polypeptide chain. Free ribosomes make cytosolic proteins; bound ribosomes make membrane/secreted proteins.

‚Üì
üìç

STEP 3: ROUGH ER

Protein folding and modification. Signal sequences direct proteins into ER lumen.

‚Üì
‚öôÔ∏è

STEP 4: GOLGI APPARATUS

Further modification, sorting, and packaging into transport vesicles.

‚Üì
üöö

STEP 5: DESTINATION

Secreted proteins ‚Üí plasma membrane ‚Üí exocytosis. Lysosomal proteins ‚Üí lysosomes. Membrane proteins ‚Üí plasma membrane.

üìù Worked Example: Protein Journey

Question: Trace the journey of an enzyme that will be secreted from a pancreatic cell, naming each organelle involved.

Answer: (1) Nucleus: Gene for enzyme is transcribed into mRNA. (2) mRNA exits nuclear pores and binds to ribosomes on the rough ER where the enzyme is synthesised. (3) Enzyme enters ER lumen for folding. (4) Transport vesicles carry enzyme to Golgi apparatus for modification and packaging. (5) Secretory vesicles transport enzyme to plasma membrane. (6) Exocytosis releases enzyme outside cell.

üóëÔ∏è

Lysosomes: Cellular Recycling

Lysosomes are membrane-bound vesicles containing hydrolytic enzymes (acid hydrolases) that break down waste materials, cellular debris, and foreign invaders. They function as the cell's recycling and waste disposal system.

FunctionDescriptionExample
DigestionBreak down macromolecules into monomersDigesting food particles brought in by endocytosis
AutophagyRecycle damaged organellesBreaking down old mitochondria (mitophagy)
ApoptosisProgrammed cell deathDigesting cell components during development
DefenceDestroy bacteria and virusesWhite blood cells digesting pathogens
üö´ Exam Trap: Lysosomes are found mainly in animal cells. Plant cells have vacuoles that perform some similar functions but true lysosomes are rare in plants. Do not say lysosomes are present in all eukaryotic cells.
‚öñÔ∏è

Animal vs Plant Cells

While animal and plant cells are both eukaryotic and share many organelles, they have distinct structural differences that reflect their different functions and lifestyles.

FeatureAnimal CellPlant Cell
Cell Wall‚ùå Absent‚úÖ Present (cellulose)
Chloroplasts‚ùå Absent‚úÖ Present (photosynthesis)
Large Central Vacuole‚ùå Small or absent‚úÖ Large, maintains turgor pressure
Lysosomes‚úÖ Present‚ùå Rare/absent (vacuole does digestion)
Centrioles‚úÖ Present (cell division)‚ùå Absent (except lower plants)
ShapeIrregular, flexibleFixed, rectangular (due to cell wall)
Energy StorageGlycogenStarch
Nucleus PositionCentralPeripheral (pushed to edge by vacuole)
üí° Shared Features: Both cell types contain: nucleus, mitochondria, ER (rough and smooth), Golgi apparatus, ribosomes, cell membrane, and cytoplasm. These shared organelles reflect their common eukaryotic ancestry.

üìã COPY INTO YOUR BOOKS

Nucleus

  • Control centre containing DNA
  • Double membrane with pores
  • Nucleolus makes ribosomes
  • Chromatin stores genetic info

Mitochondria

  • Powerhouse‚Äîproduces ATP
  • Double membrane; inner folded (cristae)
  • Own DNA (evidence for endosymbiosis)
  • Site of cellular respiration

Endomembrane System

  • Rough ER: protein synthesis + ribosomes
  • Smooth ER: lipid synthesis, detox
  • Golgi: modifies, packages, ships proteins
  • Vesicles transport between components

Lysosomes

  • Contain digestive enzymes
  • Break down waste and debris
  • Autophagy: recycle old organelles
  • Mostly in animal cells

Animal vs Plant

  • Animals: centrioles, lysosomes, no wall
  • Plants: cell wall, chloroplasts, large vacuole
  • Both: nucleus, mitochondria, ER, Golgi

Protein Pathway

  • 1. Nucleus: DNA ‚Üí mRNA
  • 2. Ribosome: mRNA ‚Üí protein
  • 3. Rough ER: folding
  • 4. Golgi: modification + packaging
  • 5. Vesicle ‚Üí destination

contentSections.title: The Nucleus: Command Centre
contentSections.content: The nucleus houses genetic material (DNA) and controls cellular activities. Contains nuclear envelope with pores, chromatin, and nucleolus.

contentSections.title: Mitochondria: Powerhouses

contentSections.title: The Endomembrane System
contentSections.content: Network of membranes including rough ER (protein synthesis), smooth ER (lipid synthesis), and Golgi apparatus (processing and packaging).

contentSections.title: Protein Synthesis and Transport
contentSections.content: Proteins travel from nucleus ‚Üí ribosome ‚Üí rough ER ‚Üí Golgi ‚Üí destination. Illustrates integrated organelle function.

contentSections.title: Lysosomes: Cellular Recycling
contentSections.content: Membrane-bound vesicles with digestive enzymes. Break down waste, recycle organelles (autophagy), and defend against pathogens.

contentSections.title: Animal vs Plant Cells
contentSections.content: Key differences: animals lack cell walls and chloroplasts; plants lack centrioles and lysosomes. Both share core eukaryotic organelles.

multipleChoice.question: Which organelle is responsible for producing ATP through cellular respiration?
multipleChoice.explanation: Mitochondria are the powerhouses of the cell, producing ATP through cellular respiration.

multipleChoice.question: What is the function of the nuclear pores?
options: To allow selective transport between nucleus and cytoplasm
multipleChoice.explanation: Nuclear pores regulate the passage of molecules between the nucleus and cytoplasm.

multipleChoice.question: Which statement correctly distinguishes rough ER from smooth ER?
options: Rough ER lacks ribosomes; smooth ER has ribosomes
Rough ER has ribosomes; smooth ER lacks ribosomes
Rough ER produces lipids; smooth ER produces proteins
There is no difference between them
multipleChoice.explanation: Rough ER is studded with ribosomes for protein synthesis, while smooth ER lacks ribosomes and synthesises lipids.

multipleChoice.question: Which feature is found in plant cells but NOT in animal cells?
multipleChoice.explanation: Plant cells have a cell wall made of cellulose; animal cells lack a cell wall.

multipleChoice.question: What is the correct order of protein transport through the endomembrane system?
multipleChoice.explanation: Proteins are synthesised on rough ER, modified in the Golgi, then transported to their final destination.

shortAnswer.question: Describe the structure of the mitochondrion and explain how its structure is adapted for ATP production.
markingCriteria: 1 mark: Cristae mentioned as folds of inner membrane
2 marks: Explanation of how cristae increase surface area for ATP synthesis
shortAnswer.modelAnswer: The mitochondrion has a double membrane structure. The outer membrane is smooth, while the inner membrane is highly folded into structures called cristae. These folds dramatically increase the surface area available for the electron transport chain and ATP synthase enzymes. Greater surface area means more proteins can be embedded in the membrane, enabling more ATP to be produced simultaneously. This structural adaptation allows mitochondria to meet high cellular energy demands efficiently.

shortAnswer.question: Outline the pathway of a secretory protein from gene to export, naming each organelle involved and its role.
markingCriteria: 1 mark: Nucleus - transcription of gene to mRNA
1 mark: Golgi apparatus - modification and packaging
shortAnswer.modelAnswer: (1) Nucleus: The gene is transcribed into mRNA which exits through nuclear pores. (2) Ribosomes on rough ER: mRNA is translated into a polypeptide chain. (3) Rough ER: The protein folds into its functional shape and enters the ER lumen. (4) Golgi apparatus: The protein is further modified, sorted, and packaged into secretory vesicles. (5) Vesicles transport the protein to the plasma membrane where exocytosis releases it outside the cell.

shortAnswer.question: Compare and contrast animal and plant cells, identifying at least three structural differences and explaining how each difference relates to function.
markingCriteria: 2 marks per difference: 1 for identifying difference, 1 for explaining function (√ó3 differences)
shortAnswer.modelAnswer: (1) Cell wall: Plant cells have a rigid cellulose cell wall providing structural support and protection; animal cells lack this, allowing flexibility for movement. (2) Chloroplasts: Plant cells contain chloroplasts for photosynthesis, enabling them to produce their own food; animal cells must obtain energy by consuming other organisms. (3) Large central vacuole: Plants have a large vacuole that maintains turgor pressure against the cell wall; animal cells have small or no vacuoles, as they do not need turgor pressure for rigidity. These differences reflect plants' sessile, autotrophic lifestyle versus animals' mobile, heterotrophic lifestyle.

assessment.question: Animal vs plant cell comparison.
assessment.answer: Cell wall (plants only) provides rigidity; chloroplasts (plants) enable photosynthesis; large vacuole (plants) maintains turgor; centrioles (animals) aid division; lysosomes (animals) digest waste.
